title: Old Basing Walks

images.title: Chris Gunns / Old Basing tithe barn
images.caption: Tithe barn

images.title: Dr Neil Clifton / The Gateway, Basing House, Old Basing, Hampshire
images.caption: he Gateway, Basing House. Basing House, (formerly Basing Castle) was the seat of the Royalist Paulet family and was besieged for three years during the Civil War by the Parliamentary forces under Cromwell. Afterwards there was not a lot left, but this gateway is original. The ruins are open to the public in summer from Wednesday to Sunday each week.

images.title: Dr Neil Clifton / Miniature horses, Old Basing, Hampshire
images.caption: Miniature horses. Often mistakenly referred to as Shetland ponies, these miniature horses are a distinctive breed, often in demand as pets.

description: This circular walk explores the village of Old Basing in Basingstoke, Hampshire. The area includes the historic Basing House, a Tudor Tithe Barn, Basingstoke Common and the Basing Lime Pits. The walk starts in the village close to Basing House which is one of the primary features of the area. It was built in the 16th century and was the home of the Marquesses of Winchester for several generations before being destroyed during the English Civil War. You can now explore the Tudor ruins and gardens which are operated and funded by Hampshire Cultural Trust. After exploring the house you can make your way south west across the common to visit the Basing Lime Pits. There's more nice trails around this park and another parking area if you would like to start the walk from here. The route then heads north east past the civil war earthworks to return to the start point.
